Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Wastewater Treatment as a Conduit and Control of Emerging Respiratory Viruses in the Environment

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1351188
Wigginton

Respiratory tract infections in humans, caused by viruses, are a major cause of deaths worldwide and they are becoming more prevalent at an increasing rate. Two recent examples of this are the severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) and the Middle Eastern respiratory syndrome (MERS). Recently, it has been shown that these can be transmitted through fecal matter and hence they may be present in wastewater. Before recommendations can be provided to deal with the release of respiratory viruses to the environment, the actual infective virus loads must be assessed. This proposed study will determine what typical concentration of respiratory tract viruses are in wastewater. These data will allow the those in the area of wastewater treatment to formulet plans on how to control these threats.

To seek answers to this problem, during this study the following three research tasks are included:

1) Develop an integrated cell culture/mass spectrometry (ICC-MS) method that simultaneously identifies enveloped respiratory virus strains and confirms their infective state;
2) Assess levels of infective enveloped respiratory viruses in raw wastewater and through a standard wastewater treatment plant over a period of two years, and,
3) Conduct bench-scale experiments to optimize selected wastewater treatment steps for respiratory virus removal under background and heightened viral load conditions that would be possible during an outbreak or seasonal peaks.

This research plan will provide a unique and urgently needed information on the fate of infective respiratory viruses in wastewater. To date, research on viruses in the aquatic environment has focused almost entirely on detecting the presence and infectivity of enteric viruses, despite the fact the respiratory viruses are likely present. If high levels of infective respiratory viruses are present in wastewater, then the results may lead to widespread modifications in wastewater treatment and the adoption of outbreak preparedness plans. Alternatively, if results suggest minimal infective respiratory viruses in wastewater and wastewater products, then the information will provide valuable reassurance to the public, particularly during otherwise stressful outbreak events.

To disseminate the results of this project to both the public and to wastewater agencies, professional workshops on pathogens in wastewater treatment will be developed. For the younger students an interactive exhibit on wastewater treatment processes and research for the Ann Arbor Hands on Museum will be developed.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Many of the viruses responsible for high-profile diseases consist of are due to enveloped viruses (e.g., severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS), Middle East respiratory syndrome (MERS), and influenza viruses). Historically, human enveloped viruses have been assumed to be either entirely absent from municipal wastewater, surface waters, and drinking waters, or else rapidly inactivated in the case that they are released to water. In fact, certain enveloped viruses can enter wastewater and surface waters, and can survive long periods of time. Prior to this research, our state of knowledge on the mechanistic fate of enveloped viruses in aquatic environments was extremely limited. This was, in part, due to a lack of methods appropriate for enriching and detecting infectious enveloped viruses in water samples. To address these knowledge gaps, this NSF CAREER project aimed to 1) evaluate the survival, partitioning, and recovery of model enveloped viruses in wastewater, 2) characterize the reactivity of enveloped viruses with the common disinfectants free chlorine and UV254, and 3) develop novel recovery and detection methods for monitoring infectious human viruses in water samples. The major results of these three aims and the associated project publications are listed below.

  1. For the first aim, we employed four model viruses?two that were enveloped viruses and two that were nonenveloped viruses?and used plaque assays to track the inactivation and partitioning of the model enveloped viruses in raw wastewater. We developed sorption and inactivation models to simulate our experimental data, and these models provided critical insight into the different fates of model enveloped viruses and model nonenveloped viruses. Our results demonstrated that model enveloped viruses do survive in wastewater, particularly at cooler water temperatures. We also demonstrated that a larger fraction of model enveloped viruses partitioned to the solids in municipal wastewater than nonenveloped viruses. With the knowledge gained from the survival and partitioning experiments, we optimized an ultrafiltration method for recovering infectious enveloped viruses from wastewater. This work resulted in the following publication:
    • Ye, Yinyin, Robert M. Ellenberg, Katherine E. Graham, and Krista R. Wigginton. "Survivability, partitioning, and recovery of enveloped viruses in untreated municipal wastewater." Environmental Science & Technology 50, no. 10 (2016): 5077-5085.
  2. In the second aim, the reactions that take place in virus lipids, proteins, and genomes were tracked as a model enveloped virus (Phi6) was treated with disinfectants using quantitative lipid and protein mass spectrometry, as well as RT-qPCR. We found that protein reactions drive the inactivation of the model enveloped virus by free chlorine, and genome reactions drive the inactivation of the model enveloped virus by UV254. Our results identified that virus proteins in the enveloped model were more susceptible to oxidant attack than the proteins in the nonenveloped model virus. This work resulted in the following publication:
    • Ye, Yinyin, Pin Hsuan Chang, John Hartert, and Krista R. Wigginton. "Reactivity of enveloped virus genome, proteins, and lipids with free chlorine and UV254." Environmental Science & Technology 52, no. 14 (2018): 7698-7708.
  3. The final aim of this project focused on developing an integrated cell culture-mass spectrometry (ICC-MS) method for detecting infectious human viruses in water. In our proof of concept experiments, we detected human reoviruses samples collected throughout a wastewater treatment plant. Our results suggest that ICC-MS is a promising tool for monitoring infectious enveloped or nonenveloped viruses in water samples. The 2019 publication resulting from this work was selected as the cover story for ES&T Letters:
    • Ye, Yinyin, Linbo Zhao, Michael J. Imperiale, and Krista R. Wigginton. "Integrated Cell Culture-Mass Spectrometry Method for Infectious Human Virus Monitoring." Environmental Science & Technology Letters 6, no. 7 (2019): 407-412.

For the education and outreach portions of this CAREER projejct, I developed a peer activity for my junior course (CEE 365 Environmental Engineering Principles) to teach students about how peer review processes are used for public research funding and publication. In this unit, students developed a 1-page proposal on what the local wastewater treatment plant could do with their residual biosolids if they upgraded their processes to produce Class A biosolids. The students each reviewed 3 of their peers' proposals in a blind-blind peer review activity. They were ultimately graded on the quality of their proposals and the quality of the peer reviews. I also lead the development of an on-site urine separation facility in my building at UM that serves as both a source of urine for urinary track virus sampling and as a demonstration site for visitors to see how human biological wastes can safely be converted to valuable products.
